Dr Rania’s Reflections 

Thank you for sharing these wonderful writings and providing this space for reflection. Bismillah. I would like to start with the Bismillah in the editor's intro. I found it revealing and thought-provoking to mention the Prophet (S) as the ultimate example of someone exhibiting holistic human health. 


There are many thikrs of praise speaking of him as the best of creation: “kheir al khalqi kullihi”, or that the Prophet (S) is perfect it’s as if he chose for himself his qualities and features. 


I found it thought-provoking because I thought of the Prophet Muhammad (S) as an example of a beautiful life, one that is meaningful, powerful, kind, generous, spiritual, religious, communal, faithful, and ultimately merciful. It hadn’t occurred to me to consider him the epitome of holistic health. In part because he died relatively young by modern standards - and in part because that framing is rare.

This stands out to me as a sort of simplified narrative: “An inability to reconcile between the

mind-body problem ultimately led to the loss of Christian scholastic theologians and its eventual abandonment in exchange for the dominance of a physicalist monism (See chapter 6).” - I’ll wait for chapter 6, in part because I believe understanding what happened in the west to fragment the world (anti-tawheed) - into self, nature, other, mind, body is a large part of where so many cascading problems stem from and a deep understanding of the tradeoffs and purposes is necessary. I don’t believe the devil can invent new ideas wholesale; he can only leverage a crack that already exists. 


One thing I loved is learning about the existence of “cookbooks” - I would love to gather all examples of detailed methods, attempt to analyze them for their intended impact areas (qalb/nafs/jasad…etc), and see if we can find themes and recipes. Al- Suhrwardī also provided a detailed elaboration of the operations of the spiritual path, including etiquette of the spiritual lodge, specific spiritual interventions (such as spiritual songs, or samāʿ), the 40- day spiritual retreat, the spiritual guide and student relationship, and the everyday protocols for the spiritual aspirant (including mundane daily acts such as eating, sleeping, time management, etc.), which provide a rich source to draw from when developing Islamic spiritually integrated interventions today.”


Thinking about Gaza today and my feelings - I’m also reflecting on this: “He says: “As for sadness that does not bring about a benefit nor displace a harm, there is no benefit in it, and God does not command that which has no benefit … However, some forms of sadness are divinely rewarded … including sorrow over the calamities of the Muslims in general” (Ibn Taymiyyah, 2004, pp. 13– 14). “

Question: My sadness … does it bring a benefit or displace a harm? And if it doesn’t do either, should I sustain it, given it may be divinely rewarded? 


Next element I’m still grappling with is this section from Ibn Taymiyyah: “He explored the relationship between cognitive and emotional states and how some thoughts have emotional underpinnings even if they appear to be rational (e.g. prejudice leading to confirmation bias). He argued that only by examining the world through revelation could we rid ourselves of the limitations to human rationality and emotions in order to acquire ultimate truths (An- Najār, 2004).”

I understand the claim that our reason is unreasonable, and likely invisible to us how we can be biased: “post-hoc justifications,” etc. I think Ibn Taymiyyah would have found split-brain research especially fascinating. The difficult part for me is understanding how he claims to break the loop. Islam often claims that this is a religion for those who look, see, think, contemplate. The question is what faculty is doing that? How do they relate? How does that break the recursive loop of using reason to come to faith and then reforming (cleaning?) your reason with your faith to gain “ultimate truths”.

And following up on the previous theme around the use of reason and logic, we find this quote: “Unlike his great predecessors al- Kindī, Ibn Sīnā, and Ibn Rushd, who had defended philosophy using Islam, Ibn al- Qayyim defended Islam using philosophy’s descendants, namely mathematics, astronomy, physics, and logic (Livingston, 1992).” - from a superficial glance it seems these two scholars are at odds. One uses the tools of reason (logic, physics…) to defend Islam, and the other suggests that Islam must be the tool that reforms epistemologies to have sound knowledge. This tension is one I’d love to resolve. 


The final tension I’d like to think about is the quote about music:

“Despite historical tension at times between physicians and theologians, their respective domains were largely respected and at times accommodations (rukhaṣ) were made for medically proven interventions to be utilized medicinally that would otherwise not be acceptable for recreational use. For example, permissions were granted by Jurists (fuqahā’) for normatively sanctioned, music therapies to be utilized in hospitals treating the mentally ill. In the 15th century Edirne Mental Hospital in Turkey, music therapies were utilized in a treatment facility located next to a madrasah (Sengul, 2015) resulting in

juxtaposition of the contemporary sciences and traditional Islamic disciplines. “


This seems a bit counterintuitive and confusing to me. It’s beautiful to say, although if we were claiming that music is normatively sanctioned, it’s unlikely to have been developed to the extent that it can now be thought of as a potential form of healing. Similarly, in psychiatry and psychedelic treatments, is it possible that there are limits to what can be explored that might happen to be helpful interventions, and perhaps sometimes the only intervention that works? How do we open a door to examine in forbidden territories to find the things that might work? Do we wait for the rebels and then tame them? It reminds me of Rumspringa among the Amish, where they ask their youth to travel and live outside the confines of their tradition for a year, and then to choose to return. 
Reflection for week 3/4 

I have been thinking about what real healing is, and my reading and learning about all these beautiful institutions reminds me of the fable of the elephant, each of the spaces with its uniqueness shows the similarities across them. We can see, like Dr. Sherman Jackson says. Islam is like a clear river; when you look through it, you know the color of the land and culture it flows over. Masha’allah 

It is inspiring to read about the values behind these beautiful institutions as well as the wuquuf mechanisms to enact those values over time. The insight that the Prophet himself (S) mentioned the idea of people with mental health issues being except from takleef(being held to account:”



The Prophet's (st) saying, 'Three persons are released from responsibility: The child until they reach the age of puberty, the sleeper until they wake up, and the majnun/ma'tuh (one who is mad or mentally ill) until they are cured' (Tirmidhi, 1423)

Taking that alongside this verse: And do not give the weak-minded your property, which Alläh (s) has made a means of sustenance for you, but provide for them with it and clothe them and speak to them words of appropriate kindness.

The Qur'ăn (4:5)



We can combine them with the idea that there is a healing for every illness, as mentioned in another hadith. This is striking to me and I am opening up to an understanding that people who work in the field of mental health have such a beautiful opportunity to help others haqiq maqasid al shari3a(the purpose of shari3a). While it’s kind and merciful of the Most Merciful not to hold them to account, what is more beautiful is to help people become the representatives of God they were meant to be. We are here to be 3badat al Rahamn, worshippers of the merciful. The job that a family does is beautiful, raising a child into the age of takleef. And takleef means they are now ready to be representatives of the Most Merciful on this earth, opening a portal for them to “visit the sick, feed the poor, etc” - to be a representation of God on Earth. To be able to fulfil the purpose, filled with rich embodied meaning and motivation, to worship God (swt). Similarly, those who see their roles as people who treat and take care of the mentally ill can bring people back into takleef, and insha’allah back into worship and khilafa. Masha’allah, I just found a beautiful intention for anyone in the Islamic mental health field, if they see and choose to take it. Hamdillah.



I had a beautiful insight as well about how Islam opens up an excuse for us to excuse people’s problematic behaviors as well. I had a cousin who saw someone get very angry and then say horrible things. He simply said, It’s ok, he is ‘insane’, insha’allah God (swt) won’t hold him accountable. This flexibility is a beautiful understanding of how we should be merciful to the world.

While reading about all the different maristans, I had a thought about the Prophet (S)’s love of incense and perfumes, and was wondering if there was any research to bring the fact that he loved perfumes and bridge it with the apothecaries and the Rab’‑I­ Rashīdī­  rose‑water­ store room, masha’allah.

Trans-Dynastic Legal Frameworks?

Another thing is that each of these maristan lasted for centuries and often across multiple dynasties. How did the wuquuf find validity as administrations changed? What were the trans-dynastic legal frameworks that were in place, or did some Maratha sultans fall once another dynasty came in, even if they were from a muslim background? 



Another insight that I found was the idea that in the Dar al-shifà ' Hyderabad, the doctors were those who brought 'the breath that brings life to the dying’. And that all Islamic treatment is actually palliative because we all accept and acknowledge the reality of death. In Dr. Verala’s Book “Embodied Cognition,” he mentions the story of a monk requesting the permission of the Dalai Lama to treat his leg, which was due for amputation. He mentions that he could conduct his meditations to do the healing. Yet, he wanted “ithn” - permission so that it wouldn’t be for himself, he wanted permission to heal his leg so he can continue the mission the Dalai Llama sent him to America for. There apparently is some X-ray evidence to demonstrate this “miracle”. How incredible the idea of ithn..  The idea of our curing isn’t for ourselves to live a “longer, healthier life” - it’s to bring life to the dying, which is all of us. To bring us life so long as we can be in khidma as long as we are alive and to return our souls with a body and mind well used and well taken care of into the grave, insha’allah.

It reminds me of the duaa of the Prophet (S):

Arabic:  اللَّهُمَّ أَحْيِنِي مَا كَانَتِ الحَيَاةُ خَيْرًا لِي، وَتَوَفَّنِي إِذَا كَانَتِ الوَفَاةُ خَيْرًا لِي.

Meaning: “O Allah, keep me alive as long as life is good for me, and take me in death when death is better for me.”

and 

إِنْ لَمْ يَكُنْ بِكَ غَضَبٌ عَلَيَّ فَلَا أُبَالِي، غَيْرَ أَنَّ عَافِيَتَكَ هِيَ أَوْسَعُ لِي.

Meaning: “If You are not angry with me, then I do not mind; yet Your well-being (relief) is more expansive for me.”

So my main takeaways from this reading that stand out are that we are here not to heal for the person themselves, we are here to help them find balance and healing so they can be a portal for God’s mercy, for as long as it is good for them to be alive. And to help them transition when that time has come, insha’allah. And may God SWT correct my understanding.

I’m interested in reviewing these papers: 
Nevertheless, it deserves attention, especially since empirical evidence shows that the quality of the therapeutic relationship itself (Baier et al., 2020; Norcross & Lambert, 2019; Weck et al., 2015) and the personal characteristics of the clinician (Heinonen et al., 2012; Heinonen & Nissen-Lie, 2020) may influence the success of therapeutic processes regardless of the specific methods used.

A common refrain is: “it doesn’t matter what you do, it matters how you do it” - also some of the things we’re talking about with Dr. Mazen reminds me of this, particularly the idea of homeopathy. Somehow the most important thing isn’t the physical mollecule interaction that matters, it’s the… metaphysical presence that transforms. To be honest I am not yet converted. Some things that give creedence to the idea for me is the hadith of the porphet (S) asking his sahaba, who had developed an impromptu sort of healing method (rukya) by reciting suratul Fatiha on the ailing person, how they had come up with that method and then praising them for it. As well as knowing that Allah (swt) is ultimately the shafi and we are here attempting to open up channels of asbab (ways/methods). The sunnatullah, in my understanding, is simply a pattern that God (swt) allows as a mercy for us, such that we can have a usually predictable and consistent life and to also support and promote the ultimat ends and desires for God (swt) to show us his mercy and care, and to bring us closer to him. 

A sunnah of life could have been that as we age we do not go through a bell curve, that we get older, healthier, our immune system sees more pathogens and gets stronger and soon we no longer fall ill, we continue to grow in strength and intelligence, etc, and then at the age of 63+, we can have a collapse of our system and we die. Except that’s not how God intended it for us. He promised us pain and difficulty, particularly for those he loves. Aging is simply a sign of his mercy if he allows it for you, we start to recognize weakness, and need and experience various age related difficulties that allow us to develop in humility, mercy towards others, patience, and turning back towards God(swt). 

Connecting this to the idea of why our practitioners must also take it upon themselves to develop their akhlaq, might be because the ultimate healing is to acknolwedge the Prophet (S)’s recognition, in a brief paraphrase, that everything in the end is of benefit for the believer, if it’s good and they are greatful they are increased, and if it’s bad and they are patient they are rewarded. This happens best when the practitioner themselves takes care of their spiritual health, making wudhu before an interaction and praying for their patients. This offers windows for asbaab that are less interventionist without breaking the sunnan of Allah (swt) for having asbab. For instance after praying for their patient and the patient recovering quickly, we have evidence of an empirical nature of what works, although it must be noted that it is highly contextualized and dependant on seen and unseen factors. I am reminded of a doctor who used to do ruqya and treat his patients and read Al Fatiha for them and they would be cured. His protege and student took his place when he passed away, and people would still come, and he would say, in effect: “I’m doing the same thing, and I am not my teacher…” 

These multi-faceted holistic exploration of natural-law “Asbaab” and “sunnan of Allah(swt) as well as more inward and spiritual work seem to me to be something critical not simply for the healing of an individual coming to a maaristaan. The movements towards “Don’t Die” and life-extention and viewing death as a disease all are demonstrating cancer-like behaviors for humanity. ### ⚗️ “Nature & observation → clinical notes, al-Rāzī’s trials”
This phrase compresses **how that epistemology played out historically**—particularly in **Abū Bakr al-Rāzī (Rhazes, 854–925 CE)**, one of the earliest and most rigorous Muslim physicians and empiricists.

Here’s what it means, line by line:

#### “Nature & observation”
→ Al-Rāzī and other early Muslim physicians grounded their practice in **close observation of patients and natural phenomena**, not only in Galenic theory or pure speculation.  
He explicitly said that **reason and observation** must test what earlier doctors wrote.

#### “→ clinical notes”
→ He kept **systematic case notes**—recording symptoms, treatments, and outcomes of patients.  
That was radical at the time; he’s often credited as one of the first clinicians to write *differential diagnoses* (e.g., distinguishing smallpox from measles).

#### “al-Rāzī’s trials”
→ This refers to his **experimental method**: al-Rāzī actually ran *controlled clinical trials*.  
The most famous example:

> When choosing where to build a hospital in Baghdad, he hung **meat in different districts** and chose the site where it decayed slowest—inferring it had the healthiest air quality.

and in medicine:

> He compared **different treatments for the same illness** and documented which ones produced better outcomes — an early version of a **comparative trial**.

> *The intellectual heritage of Islamic psychology and medicine took the study of the psyche and body seriously by observing nature and people directly, keeping empirical notes, and running experiments—epitomized by al-Rāzī’s clinical trials.*
